Colin,

Sometimes our view of evolution is colored by our often unquestio=
ned assumption that greater complexity is a good or necessary thing. Instea=
d, generally biological fitness decreases with greater complexity. A vanill=
a single-celled organism is more optimal in some reproductive sense than a =
human being. Although we have the ability to think and plan, cockroaches ar=
e more robust.

If biological fitness really is an objective in the sense o=
f how we think of it within EC (i.e. something to be maximized), then why a=
re incredibly sub-optimal solutions like humans explored? 

That is, in ter=
ms of maximizing reproduction, bacteria are much better; we are incredibly =
inefficient, taking decades and trillions of cells to replicate our DNA one=
 generation further. Most of the complexity (i.e. more cells, longer more c=
omplex life cycles) that we appreciate in nature is deleterious to replicat=
ion rate and thus deleterious to this supposed objective. 

So I don't thin=
k that the complexity of Earth is the element missing from EC models keepin=
g them from discovering a ceaseless fountain of interesting things. It is n=
ot only that there are many different possible strategies on Earth to survi=
ve-and-reproduce that is critical, but that reproduction is not strictly op=
timized -- if it were, then natural evolution would probably converge like =
we see in EC. The issue runs deeper than the fact that sometimes deleteriou=
s mutations in natural evolution still get a chance; we are vastly inferior=
 at replicating when compared to bacteria and yet are successful within our=
 own niche.

A potential thought experiment is to imagine the optimal repli=
cating single-celled organism; it would not be incredibly interesting, but =
would be 'the objective' if maximizing reproduction was truly what evolutio=
n is about. But this isn't what we find interesting about natural evolution=
.

I think this thought experiment demonstrates some kind of profound diffe=
rence between typical EC approaches and natural evolution. The convergent n=
ature of EC contrasts sharply with the divergent nature of natural evolutio=
n. But this convergence is not due to the greater domain complexity of Eart=
h that natural evolution exploits, but a certain openness of the search pro=
cess in nature to different types of solutions regardless of their global o=
ptimality. In EC we globally maximize fitness while the most interesting pr=
oducts of natural evolution do not.

A different view of evolution might be=
 that fitness is encouraged relative to the niche an organism inhabits, but=
 the absolute value of fitness is not what is 'interesting' about the artif=
acts evolution discovers as much as they just do pretty good within the con=
text of that niche. Whatever can reproduce does; different niches, even if =
they are suboptimal when compared to other niches, still accumulate. Howeve=
r, in EC, all individuals are generally judged on the same scale of fitness=
 regardless of what strategy they take. I think this is an important differ=
ence.

I do agree that the kinds of objectives used in EC are generally nar=
rowly defined and do not offer much room for alternative strategies, which =
is a problem. But this problem may be merely a symptom of the reigning abst=
raction of natural evolution within EC, that of evolution as an optimizer. =
That is, nearly any objective will just lead to convergence if the reward s=
cheme is strictly optimizing that objective. For example, even in a simple =
pole-balancing domain, there are likely different incredibly complex and in=
efficient ways of balancing that pole -- these might be analogous to 'human=
-beings' within that domain, but we would never find them by looking for an=
 efficient pole balancer; instead we might look for many different interest=
ing (but not necessarily optimal) ways of balancing a pole.

Joel
